cricket.i:
**Standard Format: Default to ‚ÄúDD Month YYYY‚Äù for all dates**
Ex.:
-**"January fifteenth" ‚Üí 15 January 2025**
-**"March three" ‚Üí 3 March 2025**
-**"January fifteenth twenty twenty-four" ‚Üí 15 January 2024**
**Year Expansion: Always expand to four digits**
-**"twenty-five" (referring to year) ‚Üí 2025**
-**"twenty-four" (referring to year) ‚Üí 2024**
**Date with Ordinal vs. Cardinal: Default to cardinal**
-**"twenty-first" ‚Üí 21**
**Month Names: Spell out in full**
-**Jan ‚Üí January**
**Numerical-only dates:**
-**"twelve ten twenty five" ‚Üí 10 December 2025**
-**"three fifteen twenty four" ‚Üí 15 March 2024**

**Well-known Date Exceptions:**
-**"nine eleven" ‚Üí 9/11 (referring to September 11, 2001)**

**Standard Format**
***Transcribe time as h:mmAM/PM; no periods and no space***
‚úÖ ‚Äú9 in the evening‚Äù ‚Üí 9:00PM**
**Time in a Series**
**Repeat the unit with each number.**
‚úÖ ‚ÄúPeople have about a 20-minute, 25-minute, maybe a 30-minute drive‚Äù**
**Time Ranges**
**Use hyphen with no spaces.**
‚úÖ ‚ÄúThey went to work from 9:00AM-5:00PM‚Äù
**Follow standard time format when converting:**
‚úÖ ‚Äú7:00AM to midnight‚Äù ‚Üí 7:00AM‚Äì12:00AM
‚úÖ ‚Äú7:00AM to 12 noon‚Äù ‚Üí 7:00AM‚Äì12:00PM
**Non-Clock Durations**
**For minutes, hours, or months not tied to a clock:**
‚úÖ ‚Äúeight to 10 minutes‚Äù (following number rule: spell out 1‚Äì9, use numerals for 10+)
‚úÖ ‚Äú24 to 36-month average‚Äù
‚úÖ ‚Äú22 to 36-hour process‚Äù

**Numerical Ranges with Same Units**
Use **"to"** when the speaker dictates a range between two numbers for readability
Apply the appropriate symbol ($ and ISO codes) to only the first number in the range.
**Apply the trillion/billion/million to only the 2nd number in the range.**
**Examples:**
‚úÖ Revenue guidance of $2.4 to 2.5 billion
**Dictated as: "two point four to two point five billion dollars"**
‚úÖ EPS guidance of $3.50 to 3.75
Dictated as: "three fifty to three seventy-five" (implied currency)
**Special Range Rules**
**When writing percentages ranges, apply the % symbol for both numbers in the range, even if the speaker only says it once**
‚úÖ EBITDA margin of 22% to 25%
Dictated as: "twenty-two to twenty-five percent"
**When "between...and" is dictated: Retain "and"**
‚úÖ Expected growth between 15% and 20% (dictated "and", retain "and")
**Value changes over time:** Retain "to"
‚úÖ grew from $100 to 150 million (change in value over time, indicating a $50 million increase)
**Different units: Use "to" not hyphen**
‚úÖ 17% to $1.1 billion (not "17%-$1.1 billion")
‚úÖ improved from 13% to $1.3 billion (different units)
**Exception for Positive/Negative Ranges:** When a range contains both positive/plus (+) and negative/minus (-) numbers, retain "to" for readability to avoid double symbols
‚úÖ +2% to -3% (clear and readable)
‚ùå +2%--3% (confusing double hyphen)

Financial Amounts: **Do Not convert to Actual Dollar Values; only convert to Actual Dollar Values if there is an explicit numeric reference in audio,** i.e. ‚Äútwo hundred million dollars‚Äù ‚Üí $200 million
quarter of a million dollars ‚Üí quarter of a million dollars
half a million seats ‚Üí half a million seats
half a billion dollars ‚Üí half a billion dollars
**Market Share/Revenue Fractions:** Use Numerical Format
a third of the market share ‚Üí 1/3 of the market share
a quarter of the revenue ‚Üí 1/4 of the revenue
**Ratio-Style Fractions:** Use XX/XX Format
Fifty-fifty ‚Üí 50/50
Context example: "It used to be 60/40. Now, it's half and half" ‚Üí "It used to be 60/40. Now, it's 50/50"
**Beginning of Sentence Exception**
Exception: At the beginning of a sentence ‚Üí A third of the market share...
Standard: Mid-sentence ‚Üí This is 1/3 of the market share
**Non-numerical Fractions**: Keep as is
half the time (retain as is)
Half-mile, half-dozen (retain as is)
"half of the population", "half of the employees" (retain as is)

***Basis Points vs Percentage Points**
**Basis Points:** Always spell out **"basis points"** (not "bps")
- "Margin expanded by 150 basis points to 22.5%"
**Percentage Points:** Use **‚Äúpercentage points‚Äù** only when dictated as such (**not** %).
- ‚ÄúRevenue increased by 3 percentage points‚Äù (not 3%)
**Multiples and Ratios**
- Use lowercase ‚Äúx‚Äù for financial multiples and ratios.
‚úÖ ‚Äú15.2x revenue multiple‚Äù 
‚úÖ ‚Äú3.5x debt-to-equity ratio‚Äù
‚úÖ ‚Äúincreased by 5x‚Äù (audio: ‚Äúfive times‚Äù)

Do **not** confuse multiples with the number of instances. Use **‚Äútimes‚Äù** when referring to frequency or repetition.
‚úÖ ‚ÄúWe met five times last quarter.‚Äù ‚ùå ‚ÄúWe met 5x last quarter‚Äù
‚úÖ ‚ÄúThe stock price rose three times in a row.‚Äù
**Time Periods**
- **Years:** 2024, 2025 (not '24 - expand years)
- **Quarters:** Default to this format ‚Äî Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4; **Do Not** deviate to ‚Äú1Q‚Äù or ‚Äúthird quarter‚Äù or ‚Äúquarter two‚Äù)
**Comparative periods:** year-over-year, quarter-over-quarter

**Mathematical Operations: Use + Symbol**
- "10 ml plus 10 ml of a drug" ‚Üí 10 ml + 10 ml of a drug
**Estimates/Approximations: Use + After Numbers**
- "seven point five plus years" ‚Üí 7.5+ years
- "eight plus percent" ‚Üí 8%+
**Positive/Negative Numbers: Use +/- Before Numbers**
- "positive eight percent" ‚Üí +8%
- "negative eight percent" ‚Üí -8%
**Plus or Minus: Use ¬± Symbol**
- ONLY when speakers explicitly say "plus or minus"
- "Plus or minus 75%" ‚Üí ¬±75%
**Contextual/Narrative Use: Retain as Words**
- "Revenue plus operating costs" ‚Üí Revenue plus operating costs
cricket.l: Plus, Minus, and Numerical Symbol Usage

cricket.i:
**Core Editing Principles**
**ALWAYS EDIT (Critical Transcript Content)**
**Speaker Tags:** Format as FirstName LastName [Position] (Company), or Operator
**Financial Figures:** Correct amounts, symbols, and formatting
**Company Names:** Verify spelling against Style Guide/official sources
**Executive Names:** Verify spelling and titles
**Industry Terms:** Ensure technical accuracy when transcript-critical
**Punctuation & Sentence Structure:* Correct obvious errors (e.g., misplaced question marks), and fix transcript cuts by merging or splitting sentences appropriately
***Fillers & Conjunctions:** Remove um, uh and unnecessary starters (And, But, So), only if doing so does not alter / impact the meaning of the sentence.
**Run-on Sentences:** Break at natural conjunction points
**Terminal Punctuation:** Ensure all sentences end correctly
**Paragraph Splicing:** Keep paragraphs concise (max 6 lines) for readability
**DO NOT EDIT (Preserve Authenticity)**
**Speaker Intent:** Do not change meaning
**Meaningful Fillers:** Keep you know, I mean, like, actually, well
**False Starts:** Retain natural speech patterns
**Conversational Flow:** Maintain authentic communication
**Implied Dialogue/Direct Speech:** Do not add quotation marks to reported speech or implied dialogue, retain as is

-1. Is this a Core Pillar item? (**Speaker tag, proper noun, financial figure, sentence structure**)
**‚úÖ YES ‚Üí Use the audio. Edit accordingly while applying Style Guide rules**
‚ùå NO ‚Üí Go to step 2
-2. Is this a speech pattern? (verbal crutches, fillers, contractions, direct speech/implied dialogues, etc.)
**‚úÖ YES ‚Üí Keep the transcript as-is (ignore audio differences)**
‚ùå NO ‚Üí Go to step 3
-3. Is this general speech/casual conversation?
**‚úÖ YES ‚Üí Keep transcript as-is**
‚ùå NO ‚Üí Use judgment. If it falls under Core Pillars, edit accordingly

**[Operator]**
The neutral host managing technical flow (opening/closing, instructions, Q&A queue)
*****Do not tag as ‚ÄúModerator‚Äù*****
**FirstName LastName [Position] (Company)**
‚Ä¢ Key executives (CEO, CFO) leading the call 
‚Ä¢ Company representatives (Investor Relations) facilitating Q&A
‚Ä¢ Analysts, investors asking questions 
‚Ä¢ If substitute speaks for originally introduced participant, use substitute's name
**[Analyst]**
‚Ä¢ Name: Unknown, No firstname and last name
‚Ä¢ Role: Analyst (confirmed) 
‚Ä¢ Company: Unknown
**[Analyst] (Company Name)**
‚Ä¢ Name: Unknown 
‚Ä¢ Role: Analyst (confirmed) 
‚Ä¢ Company: Known
‚ö†Ô∏èLAST RESORT 
‚Ä¢ No information available at all
‚Ä¢ Cannot determine role or company
**[Analyst] (Company Name)**
‚Ä¢ Name: Only the first name is available; the last name cannot be determined from the transcript or research.
‚Ä¢ Role: Analyst (confirmed) 
‚Ä¢ Company: Known
*****‚ö†Ô∏è Do not use just the first name if the last name is unknown ‚Üí use [Analyst] (Company Name) instead.*****
**[Company Representative]**
‚Ä¢ Name: Unknown 
‚Ä¢ Role: Company Representative (confirmed) 
‚Ä¢ Company: Unknown
‚Ä¢ Name: Unknown 
‚Ä¢ Role: Company Representative (confirmed) 
‚Ä¢ Company: Known

Add numbers only when multiple speakers have identical tags
*****Examples:***** [Analyst 1], [Analyst 2]
No numbers needed when companies differ: [Analyst] (AT&T) and [Analyst] (Morgan Stanley)

**Two Positions**
**‚úÖ CORRECT:** [CEO and President]
Use "and" spelled out
**‚ùå INCORRECT:**
[CEO & President] - Don't use ampersand
[CEO&President] - No spaces with ampersand
[CEOandPresident] - Missing spaces
**Three or More Positions**
**‚úÖ CORRECT:** [Executive Chairman, President, and CEO]
Use Oxford comma (comma before "and")
Use "and" spelled out
**‚ùå INCORRECT:**
[Executive Chairman, President and CEO] - Missing Oxford comma
[Executive Chairman, President, & CEO] - Using ampersand
[Executive Chairman, President & CEO] - No Oxford comma and using ampersand
**Title Abbreviations**
Use recognized acronyms in tags: CEO, CFO, COO, CMO, VP, EVP
Even if speaker says full title: "Chief Executive Officer" ‚Üí [CEO]
Important: Only abbreviate in speaker tags, NOT in transcript text
**Title Capitalization**
**‚úÖ CORRECT:**
[Mining Research Analyst] - All major words capitalized
[Senior Analyst] - Proper capitalization
[Equity Research Senior Associate] - Proper capitalization
**‚ùå INCORRECT:**
[Senior analyst] - Lowercase "analyst"
[mining research analyst] - Improper capitalization

**Always refer to the list of expected attendees as the primary source.**
**Finding Complete Names**
- **First/Last name only in audio:** Use Google and context clues to find first/last name, or leverage company-provided speaker hints (if available)
**Verification sources:**
- Company websites (About Us, Leadership pages)
- LinkedIn profiles
- Recent press releases
- SEC filings for public companies
**Examples**
- Audio says "Bob" ‚Üí Research finds ‚Üí Bob Leasure [CEO and President] (Inotiv)
- Audio says "Fred" ‚Üí Research finds Frederick Bell ‚Üí Fred Bell [President and COO] (EMX Royalty)
**Name Consistency**
**Use one consistent tag per speaker** throughout transcript
**Follow the name as spoken:** If a speaker uses a nickname instead of their full name, transcribe the nickname as is (e.g., Rob instead of Robert)"

Identify dominant speaker
Use **[crosstalk]** for unintelligible overlapping speech
Mark unclear sections appropriately

When the audio is AI-generated with a single voice representing all speakers:
**Identify speakers using contextual clues from the conversation content**
Listen for:
- Self-introductions ("This is John from Microsoft...")
- References to speakers by name ("Thank you, Sarah, for that question...")
- Role-specific statements (operator instructions, analyst questions, executive responses)
- Transition phrases indicating speaker changes
**Do not assume speaker continuity based on voice similarity alone**
**Verify speaker attribution through:**
- Content consistency with speaker's role
- Q&A flow patterns (question from analyst ‚Üí answer from executive)
- Operator cues about who's speaking next
**When uncertain, use contextual markers:**
- Company representatives discuss internal metrics
- Analysts ask questions about guidance
- Operators manage call flow

Use exactly as introduced by speaker
Retain abbreviations if spoken (Audio: J&J, use J&J not Johnson & Johnson)
Include official styling when verified

- All speakers have complete tags with name, position, and company (where known)
- No spaces inside brackets or parentheses
- Single spaces between all words
- "and" used instead of "&" for positions
- Oxford comma used for 3+ positions
- Proper capitalization for all positions
- No duplicate tags for same speaker
- No "null", "Unidentified", or "Speaker #" in tags
- Unknown speakers follow priority order
- Numbers added only when necessary for identical tags

**Currency Formatting**
USD Exception (Symbol Format)
- $2.5 billion (Audio: "Two point five billion dollars") not $2,500,000
- $2.5 billion (Audio: "Two and a half billion dollars") not $2,500,000
half a billion dollars ‚Üí half a billion dollars (check Fraction rules for financial amount below)
- $1,250,000 (Audio: "One million two hundred fifty thousand dollars") not $1.25 million
- $150 million (Audio: "One hundred fifty million dollars")
- $0.50 (Audio: ‚Äú50 cents‚Äù) not 50¬¢
**All Other Currencies (ISO Code + Space)**
- EUR 1.2 billion (European Euro)
- JPY 500 billion (Japanese Yen)
- GBP 800 million (British Pound)
- CAD 500 million (Canadian Dollar)
- RMB 500 million (Chinese Yuan)
**Currency codes follow the ISO 4217 international standard. For verification of currency codes not listed, refer to:**
**ISO 4217 List:** https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217 
**Currency Codes:** https://www.xe.com/iso4217.php 
**Currency Symbol Inference**
**When No Currency Is Dictated:** If the transcript contains a number that context clearly indicates as money, the editor must supply the correct currency symbol or code.
**If Unclear Which Currency to Use:**
**Follow Call Instructions First** ‚Äì If the operator provides specific guidance, always use that.
**Use Company‚Äôs Context** ‚Äì When no specific currency instructions are provided in the call‚Äîand only if a figure is given **without a dictated currency**‚Äîinfer the currency based on the company‚Äôs context. **Important: preserve the currency in text, i.e. ‚ÄúCanadian dollars‚Äù even after adding the currency symbol.**
- US company ‚Üí $
- EU company ‚Üí EUR
- UK company ‚Üí GBP
- Japanese company ‚Üí JPY
**Currencies/Units Without Numbers**
When currency or units of measurement are mentioned without a numerical figure, spell them out in full. Do not use symbols in these cases.
‚úÖ The discussion was about the US dollar.
‚ùå The discussion was about the $.
‚úÖ He measured it in meters.
‚ùå He measured it in m.

**Numbers and Numerical Figures**
- 1-9: Spell out (one, five, eight)
- 10+: Use numerals (10, 25, 103)
- Ordinal Numbers: first-ninth (spelled out); 10th+ numerals
- Commas: Use in numbers 1,000+ (1,200; 15,000; 100,000)
- Spoken abbreviations: Convert to full numeric
- 60K ‚Üí 60,000
- 2 mil ‚Üí 2 million
- 3.2B ‚Üí 3.2 billion
**Percentages**
- **Format:** 15.5% (not fifteen point five percent)
- **Include leading zero for values less than one:** 0.25%
- **Whole numbers:** 100% (not one hundred percent)

- **Mathematical Operations:** Use + Symbol
"10 ml plus 10 ml of a drug" ‚Üí 10 ml + 10 ml of a drug
- **Estimates/Approximations:** Use + After Numbers
"seven point five plus years" ‚Üí 7.5+ years
"eight plus percent" ‚Üí 8%+
- **Positive/Negative Numbers:** Use +/- Before Numbers
"positive eight percent" ‚Üí +8%
"negative eight percent" ‚Üí -8%
- **Plus or Minus:** Use ¬± Symbol
ONLY when speakers explicitly say "plus or minus"
"Plus or minus 75%" ‚Üí ¬±75%
- **Contextual/Narrative Use:** Retain as Words
"Revenue plus operating costs" ‚Üí Revenue plus operating costs
cricket.l: Plus, Minus, and Numerical Symbol Usage

cricket.i:
**Numerical Ranges with Same Units**
- Use "to" when the speaker dictates a range between two numbers for readability
- Apply the appropriate symbol ($ and ISO codes) to only the first number in the range.
- Apply the trillion/billion/million to only the 2nd number in the range.
*****Examples:*****
‚úÖ Revenue guidance of $2.4 to 2.5 billion
- Dictated as: "two point four to two point five billion dollars"
‚úÖ EPS guidance of $3.50 to 3.75
- Dictated as: "three fifty to three seventy-five" (implied currency)
**Special Range Rules**
**When writing percentages ranges**, apply the % symbol for both numbers in the range, even if the speaker only says it once
‚úÖ EBITDA margin of 22% to 25%
Dictated as: "twenty-two to twenty-five percent"
**When "between...and" is dictated:** Retain "and"
‚úÖ Expected growth between 15% and 20% (dictated "and", retain "and")
Value changes over time: Retain "to"
‚úÖ grew from $100 to 150 million (change in value over time, indicating a $50 million increase)
** Different units:** Use "to" not hyphen
‚úÖ 17% to $1.1 billion (not "17%-$1.1 billion")
‚úÖ improved from 13% to $1.3 billion (different units)
**Exception for Positive/Negative Ranges:** When a range contains both positive/plus (+) and negative/minus (-) numbers, retain "to" for readability to avoid double symbols
‚úÖ +2% to -3% (clear and readable)
‚ùå +2%--3% (confusing double hyphen)

**Financial Amounts: Do Not** convert to Actual Dollar Values; only convert to Actual Dollar Values if there is an explicit numeric reference in audio, i.e. ‚Äútwo hundred million dollars‚Äù ‚Üí $200 million
- quarter of a million dollars ‚Üí quarter of a million dollars
- half a million seats ‚Üí half a million seats
- half a billion dollars ‚Üí half a billion dollars
**Market Share/Revenue Fractions:** Use Numerical Format
- a third of the market share ‚Üí 1/3 of the market share
- a quarter of the revenue ‚Üí 1/4 of the revenue
**Ratio-Style Fractions:** Use XX/XX Format
- Fifty-fifty ‚Üí 50/50
- Context example: "It used to be 60/40. Now, it's half and half" ‚Üí "It used to be 60/40. Now, it's 50/50"
**Beginning of Sentence Exception**
- Exception: At the beginning of a sentence ‚Üí A third of the market share...
- Standard: Mid-sentence ‚Üí This is 1/3 of the market share
**Non-numerical Fractions:** Keep as is
- half the time (retain as is)
- Half-mile, half-dozen (retain as is)
- "half of the population", "half of the employees" (retain as is)

**Gigabytes vs. Gigabits:**
- Gigabyte (GB) = Storage capacity measurement
- Gigabit (Gb) = Data transfer speed measurement
**‚úÖ Correct Usage:**
- "Our servers have 500 GB of storage" (Audio: "five hundred gigabytes of storage")
- "The network speed is 10 Gb per second" (Audio: "ten gigabits per second")
**‚ùå Common Errors:**
- "500 Gb of storage" (should be GB)
- "10 GB per second transfer" (should be Gb)

**General Rule:** Use abbreviated forms with numerical values for consistency. Do not put a space between the numerical value and the unit of measurement. If no numerical value is present, retain the full term as spoken. If there is no explicit numeric reference in the audio, retain the text in words, i.e. ‚Äúa couple hundred pounds‚Äù.
**Distance/Length Units:**
‚úÖ 50mi, 15ft, 100km (with numbers)
‚úÖ "measured in miles" (without numbers - spell out)
**Weight/Mass Units:**
‚úÖ 250lbs, 75kg
‚úÖ tons (always write out, do not use symbol)
‚úÖ metric tons (always write out)
**Volume Units:**
‚úÖ 100gal, 50L, 1,000bbl, 500cu ft
‚úÖ MMbpd (million barrels per day - standard oil industry unit)
**Area Units:**
‚úÖ 100,000sq ft, 50sq mi
‚úÖ acres, hectares (always spell out)
**Temperature Units:**
‚úÖ degrees Fahrenheit, degrees Celsius (no symbols: ‚ùå¬∞F, ‚ùå¬∞C)

mantis.i:
Format : Month Date, Year 
*****Month Names: Spell out month names in full.*****
**January, February, March, April, May, June, July, August, September, October, November, December**
***Ex.:*** 
-**January 21, 2026**
-**"January fifteenth" ‚Üí January 15th**
-**March three" ‚Üí March 3**
-*****"January fifteenth twenty twenty-four"*** ‚Üí January 15th, 2024**
-*****"December twenty-first twenty-five"*** ‚Üí December 21st, 2025**
**Year Expansion: Always expand abbreviated years to four digits when mentioned.**
-*****"twenty-five" (when referring to a year)*** ‚Üí 2025**
-*****"twenty-four" (when referring to a year)*** ‚Üí 2024**
**Date with Ordinal/Cardinal Indicators: Use proper ordinals only if that's how dictated. If the speaker uses cardinal numbers, retain them as cardinal.**
-*****If dictated as "first, second, third"*** ‚Üí 1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.**
-*****If dictated as "one, two, three"*** ‚Üí 1, 2, 3, etc.**
***Ex.:***
-**"twenty-first" ‚Üí 21st, but "twenty-one" ‚Üí 21**
-**Jan ‚Üí January**
**Numerical-only dates: When speakers use numerical format:**
-**"twelve ten twenty five" ‚Üí 12/10/2025**
-**"three fifteen twenty four" ‚Üí 03/15/2024**
-**‚Äúsix one twenty twenty five‚Äù ‚Üí 06/01/2025**
**Well-known Date Exceptions: Retain commonly recognized numerical formats for culturally significant dates.**
-**"nine eleven" ‚Üí 9/11 (referring to the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks)**

**Numerical ranges with same units**
**Use a hyphen (-) to represent ‚Äúto‚Äù when the speaker dictates a range between two numbers.**
**Apply the appropriate symbol ($, %, etc.) to both numbers in the range, even if the speaker only says it once.**
*****Examples:*****
‚úÖ Revenue guidance of $2.4 billion-$2.5 billion
 ‚Üí Dictated as: ‚Äútwo point four to two point five billion dollars‚Äù
 ‚Üí Use a hyphen and repeat the $ symbol before both values.
‚úÖ EBITDA margin of 22%-25%
 ‚Üí Dictated as: ‚Äútwenty-two percent to twenty-five percent‚Äù
 ‚Üí Replace ‚Äúto‚Äù with a hyphen and apply % to both ends of the range.
‚úÖ EPS guidance of $3.50‚Äì$3.75
 ‚Üí Dictated as: ‚Äúthree fifty to three seventy-five‚Äù
 ‚Üí Transcribe using a hyphen, with the $ symbol shown before both figures.
**When "between...and" is dictated: Retain "and"**
‚úÖ Expected growth between 15% and 20% (dictated "and",  retain "and")
**Value changes over time: Retain "to" (not a range)**
‚úÖ grew from $100 million to $150 million (this is not a range, but a change in value over time, indicating a $50 million increase)
**Different units: Use "to" not hyphen**
‚úÖ 17% to $1.1 billion (not "17%-$1.1 billion")
‚úÖ improved from 13% to $1.3 billion (different units)

**Exception for Positive/Negative Ranges: **
When a range contains both positive/plus (+) and negative/minus (-) numbers, retain "to" for readability to avoid double hyphens.
‚úÖ +2% to -3% (clear and readable)
‚ùå +2%--3% (confusing double hyphen)

**Financial Amounts - Convert to Actual Dollar Values**
quarter million dollars ‚Üí $250,000
half a million seats ‚Üí 500,000 seats
half a billion dollars ‚Üí $500 million
**Market Share/Revenue Fractions - Use Numerical Format**
a third of the market share ‚Üí 1/3 of the market share
a quarter of the revenue ‚Üí 1/4 of the revenue
**Ratio-Style Fractions - Use XX/XX Format**
Fifty-fifty ‚Üí 50/50
Similar instances: 80/20, 70/15/15, etc.
Context example: "It used to be 60/40. Now, it's half and half" ‚Üí "It used to be 60/40. Now, it's 50/50"
**Beginning of Sentence Exception**
Exception: At the beginning of a sentence ‚Üí A third of the market share...
Standard: Mid-sentence ‚Üí 1/3 of the market share
**Range Applications**
In ranges ‚Üí 1/3 to half of the patients
With measurements ‚Üí one third to half a mg ‚Üí 0.3 mg-0.5 mg
**Vague**
Vague/non-counting: Use "one-third" or "a third" when no direct amount is attached
**Time-Based Fractions (Keep as is**)
half the time (retain as is)
Half-mile, half-dozen (retain as is)
"half of the population", "half of the employees" (retain as is)
Key Principle for Financial Editing:
Context matters - If fractions are directly impacting financial figures, convert them to numerical format or actual dollar amounts for clarity and precision in financial analysis.

**Mathematical Operations - Use + Symbol**
For actual calculations and equations between numbers.
Examples:
"10 ml plus 10 ml of a drug" ‚Üí 10 ml + 10 ml of a drug
"One plus one equals two" ‚Üí 1 + 1 = 2

**Estimates/Approximations - Use + After Numbers**
When "plus" means "or more" or indicates minimum thresholds.
Examples:
"seven point five plus years" ‚Üí 7.5+ years
"eight plus percent" or "eight percent plus" ‚Üí 8%+
"We expect eight percent plus growth" ‚Üí 8%+ growth
**Positive/Negative Numbers and Changes - Use +/- Before Numbers**
Use +/- symbols when:
- Speakers explicitly say "plus," "minus," or "negative", ‚Äúpositive‚Äù before numbers
- Reporting actual changes vs. baseline (increase/decrease)
*****Examples:*****
"plus eight percent" ‚Üí +8%
"minus eight percent" ‚Üí -8%
"negative one" ‚Üí -1
**Plus or Minus - Use ¬± Symbol**
ONLY when speakers explicitly say "plus or minus."
*****Examples:*****
"Plus or minus 75%" ‚Üí ¬±75%
75% plus or minus ‚Üí 75%¬±
**Contextual/Narrative Use - Retain as Words**
When "plus," "minus," "negative," or "positive" are used in descriptive, conceptual, or narrative context.
*****Examples:******
"Revenue plus operating costs" ‚Üí Revenue plus operating costs
"The positive aspects of the merger" ‚Üí The positive aspects of the merger
"Give or take 20%" ‚Üí Give or take 20%
*****Key Rule:***** Use symbols for mathematical or numerical contexts and directional changes. Use words when referring to descriptive or conceptual ideas.
Reminder: Extra zeroes beyond the decimal point can affect the perceived precision or implied accuracy of a figure‚Äîespecially in financial transcripts. 
*****Example,***** 4.05 billion ‚â† 4.050 billion. The latter suggests precision to the thousandth place, which may not be accurate.
mantis.l: Plus, Minus, and Numerical Symbol Usage

mantis.i:
‚úÖ EBITDA (not E.B.I.T.D.A.)
‚úÖ EPS (not E.P.S.)
‚úÖ P/E ratio (not P.E. ratio)
‚úÖ ROI (not R.O.I.)
‚úÖ M&A (not M and A)
‚úÖ IPO (Initial Public Offering)
‚úÖ SaaS (Software as a Service)
‚úÖ CRM (Customer Relationship Management)
‚úÖ ERP (Enterprise Resource Planning)

Technical Units and Common Numerical Errors
Use unit abbreviations (e.g., GW for gigawatts) only when a numerical figure is present. If no number is attached, retain the full term as spoken in the raw transcript.

Data Storage vs. Data Transfer Units
Gigabytes vs. Gigabits - Critical Distinction:
Gigabyte (GB) = Storage capacity measurement
Gigabit (Gb) = Data transfer speed measurement
‚úÖ Correct Usage:
"Our servers have 500 GB of storage" (Audio: "five hundred gigabytes of storage")
"The network speed is 10 Gb per second" (Audio: "ten gigabits per second")
"We're processing 2.5 TB of data" (Audio: "two point five terabytes of data")
"Internet speeds reached 1 Gb" (Audio: "one gigabit")
‚ùå Common Errors:
"500 Gb of storage" (should be GB)
"10 GB per second transfer" (should be Gb)
Audio Mishearing Example:
Audio: "16 gigabites"
Context: "Our new servers come with 16 gigabites of RAM"
‚úÖ Correct: "Our new servers come with 16 GB of RAM"
‚ùå Incorrect: "Our new servers come with 16 gigabites of RAM"
Technical Abbreviations Reference
Data Storage Units:
KB = Kilobyte (1,000 bytes)
MB = Megabyte (1,000,000 bytes)
GB = Gigabyte (1,000,000,000 bytes)
TB = Terabyte (1,000 GB)
PB = Petabyte (1,000 TB)
Data Transfer Speed Units:
Kb = Kilobit
Mb = Megabit
Gb = Gigabit
Mbps = Megabits per second
Gbps = Gigabits per second
Processing and Performance:
CPU = Central Processing Unit
GPU = Graphics Processing Unit
RAM = Random Access Memory
GHz = Gigahertz (processing frequency)
MHz = Megahertz (processing frequency)
API = Application Programming Interface
SDK = Software Development Kit
Network and Infrastructure:
CDN = Content Delivery Network
DNS = Domain Name System
VPN = Virtual Private Network
SSL = Secure Sockets Layer
TLS = Transport Layer Security
HTTP = Hypertext Transfer Protocol
HTTPS = HTTP Secure
Power and Energy:
W = Watt (Audio: "watt")
kW = Kilowatt (Audio: "kilowatt" or "K-W")
MW = Megawatt (Audio: "megawatt" or "M-W")
kWh = Kilowatt-hour (Audio: "kilowatt hour" or "K-W-H")
MWh = Megawatt-hour (Audio: "megawatt hour" or "M-W-H")
Other Technical Unit Distinctions
Memory vs. Processing:
‚úÖ "16 GB of RAM" (memory capacity)
‚úÖ "3.2 GHz processor" (processing speed)
‚ùå "16 Gb of RAM" (incorrect unit)
‚ùå "3.2 GB processor" (incorrect unit)
Power and Energy:
‚úÖ "5 MW power plant" (megawatts - power capacity)
‚úÖ "100 MWh battery" (megawatt-hours - energy storage)
‚ùå "5 MWh power plant" (incorrect for capacity)
Research Verification for Technical Numbers
Quick Context Checks:
Unit Appropriateness: Storage contexts use bytes (GB, TB), speed contexts use bits (Gb, Mb)
Industry Standards: Cloud storage typically measured in TB/PB, network speeds in Gb/s

Financial Figures as Modifiers or Idioms
Retain natural form - "a billion-dollar company" (not "$1-billion company")
Contextual usage - Maintain speaker's intended meaning

**QUICK REFERENCE:**
**[guess] brackets:** Core Pillar content (speakers, financials, proper nouns)
**[crosstalk]:** Multiple speakers, unintelligible content
**[Foreign language]:** Any non-English sections
**[audio distortion]:** Extremely unclear/distorted English; replace raw transcript with this tag.
**Raw transcript:** General conversation, non-critical content
**Decision Framework:**
When encountering unclear, garbled, or ambiguous audio sections, apply this decision framework:
‚úÖ USE [guess] brackets Core Pillar Impact Assessment: If the unclear section potentially involves any of the three Core Pillars, use guess brackets to provide the most likely interpretation.
‚ö†Ô∏èPlace any intelligible guess inside brackets. Do not type the word ‚Äúguess‚Äù explicitly. Think of what the word is likely to be and insert it inside brackets.
*****Example:***** 
Audio sounds like "Macrosaft" in tech company context ‚Üí [Microsoft] 
Use what you heard phonetically, then apply context to determine correct spelling
**Context Evaluation Guidelines:** 
Always base guesses on what you actually heard in the audio, even if unclear
Use context only to refine spelling, formatting, or verify the most likely intended word 
Never insert content that has no audio basis whatsoever 
If nothing intelligible can be heard and context does not make it clear, retain the raw transcript
‚úÖ USE [crosstalk] when: 
Multiple speakers talk simultaneously and content is unintelligible
Cannot identify the dominant speaker or separate clear statements
‚úÖ USE [Foreign language] when: 
Speaker uses a foreign language in an otherwise English transcript 
Apply consistently, even if you understand the foreign language 
Maintain the flow of English sentence structure
**Formatting:** Use capital F for Foreign and lowercase l for language.
*****Example:***** 
**AUDIO:** In the first quarter [speaks in Chinese] we gained valuable insights into our operations.
**TRANSCRIPT:** In the first quarter [Foreign language] we gained valuable insights into our operations."
**üìå RETAIN RAW TRANSCRIPT when unclear audio involves:**
- General conversation or speech patterns 
- Non-business-critical content 
- Verbal crutches, fillers, or casual expressions
‚úÖ** USE [audio distortion] when:**
- The audio is in English but is **extremely unclear, garbled, or distorted**, to the point that **no confident transcription is possible**, making the raw transcript completely unreliable (e.g., gibberish, severe static, audio cuts off, or loud background noise). Use [audio distortion] **only as a last resort** when it is truly impossible to understand any words.
- You are certain the content is in English, but the platform produced a raw transcript that is clearly incorrect or non-English due to severe distortion; the transcript is completely **unreliable**.
- **Do not use** [audio distortion] **for accents, dialects, minor mispronunciations, or speech patterns**‚Äîtranscribe what you can understand. ‚ö†Ô∏è If such factors make a word unclear, especially if it is likely a **core pillar**, use an **intelligent guess** instead of [audio distortion]. Do **not** type the word ‚Äúguess‚Äù; enter your best interpretation based on context.
- **Action:** Remove any incorrect transcript provided by the platform and **replace it with [audio distortion].**
*****Example:*****
 **Audio:** Muffled sentence that is difficult to understand, but you are certain it is in English and the provided transcript is far from what was actually said based on the context.
**Raw transcript:** Bonjour, comment √ßa va?
 **Edited transcript:** [audio distortion]

**QUICK REFERENCE:**
‚úÖ** ALWAYS EDIT:** Core Pillars (Speaker Tags, Financial Figures, Proper Nouns)
‚ùå **NEVER EDIT:** Speech patterns (um, uh, false starts, fillers)
Terminal punctuation: Only correct form (. vs ?) where it already exists
**Speaker Tags:** ‚úÖ ALWAYS EDIT -> Format correctly, verify names/titles
**Company Names:** ‚úÖ ALWAYS EDIT -> Correct spelling, maintain official styling	
**Executive Names:** ‚úÖ ALWAYS EDIT ->  Verify spelling and titles
**Financial Figure:** ‚úÖ ALWAYS EDIT -> Correct amounts, symbols, formatting
**Financial Metrics:** ‚úÖ ALWAYS EDIT -> Proper acronym formatting, accuracy
**Industry Terms:** ‚úÖ ALWAYS EDIT -> Correct technical terminology when business-critical
**Currency Symbols:** ‚úÖ ALWAYS EDIT -> Apply correct symbols and formatting
**Percentages:** ‚úÖ ALWAYS EDIT -> Use % symbol, proper decimal formatting
**Verbal Crutches:** -> ‚ùå NEVER EDIT ->Preserve "um," "uh," "you know"
**False Starts:** -> ‚ùå NEVER EDIT -> Maintain natural speech patterns
**Conversation Fillers:** ‚ùå NEVER EDIT -> Leave "I mean," "like," "so" unchanged
**General Misspellings:** ‚ùå NEVER EDIT -> Preserve non-business critical errors
‚ö†Ô∏è **Key Rule:** The raw transcript is your source of truth for speech patterns. Only use audio to verify the three Core Pillars (speaker tags, proper nouns, financial figures) and terminal punctuations.

ü§î**Decision-Making Guide**
When you notice a discrepancy between audio and transcript:
**Is this a Core Pillar item? (Speaker tag, proper noun, or financial figure)**
‚óã YES ‚Üí Use the audio. Edit it accordingly while applying the Style Guide rules. 
‚óã NO ‚Üí Go to step 2
**Is this a speech pattern? (verbal crutches, fillers, contractions, etc.)** 
‚óã YES ‚Üí Keep the transcript as-is (ignore audio differences) 
‚óã NO ‚Üí Go to step 3
**Is this general speech/casual conversation?** 
‚óã YES ‚Üí Keep transcript as-is 
‚óã NO ‚Üí Use your judgment. If it falls under the three core pillars, edit it accordingly while applying the Style Guide rules.

üîí Additional Preservation Rules
Always maintain:
Investor identifying information - Keep participant details as spoken
Natural speech flow - Don't alter conversational tone or pacing
Casual language - Preserve informal expressions and conversational tone
Original contractions - If speaker said "we'll" but transcript shows "we will," keep "we will"
Never use the strike-through feature to remove content that should be preserved in the transcript.

**Terminal Punctuation Rules**
Only correct the form of terminal punctuation (period vs. question mark only) where it already exists in the raw transcript. Do not add or remove terminal punctuation. Only correct the terminal punctuation as it appears. If sentence boundaries are incorrect or spliced, do not restructure or re-punctuate them even if the speaker‚Äôs intonation suggests a different sentence boundary. Always follow the transcript's structure, not the speaker‚Äôs tone or pauses. Commas around modifiers, clauses, or similar mid-sentence elements should be ignored.
Raw Transcript: ‚ùåThanks Matt what would the margin look like for Q2.
‚ùå Thanks, Matt. What would the margin look like for Q2?
‚ùå Thanks. Matt, what would the margin look like for Q2?
‚úÖ Thanks Matt what would the margin look like for Q2?

**Paragraph Splicing**
**When to splice paragraphs:**
- ONLY when the platform incorrectly combines paragraphs from two different speakers
*****Example of when splicing is needed:*****
‚ùå Platform incorrectly combines:
John Smith - CEO: Thank you for the question. Our revenue grew 15% this quarter. I'd like to turn it over to our CFO. Jane Doe, can you walk through the details? **Yes, I can walk through the details.**

‚úÖ Correct after splicing:
John Smith - CEO: Thank you for the question. Our revenue grew 15% this quarter. I'd like to turn it over to our CFO. Jane Doe, can you walk through the details? 
Jane Doe - CFO: Yes, I can walk through the details.

**NOT TO SPEND TIME ON**
Do not spend time on paragraph splicing unless speaker attribution is incorrect. Natural paragraph breaks should remain unchanged.

**Standard Format**
FirstName LastName [Position] (Company)
üìåIf a middle initial is mentioned in the audio, use it in the speaker tag. John A. Doe [Position] [Company]
üìå Note: For names with initials under the South Indian Naming System, see another subsection after Core Formatting Rules for correct handling.
**Core Formatting Rules**
- No colon after speaker tag - Platform adds colon automatically
- One tag per speaker turn - Only tag first paragraph if turn spans multiple paragraphs
Check out the explanation in this short video
- No titles in tags - Don't add Dr., Mr., Mrs. in speaker tag (but retain in transcript as spoken)
- Remove unused pre-populated tags - Delete "Speaker 7," "Speaker 6," or "Operator" if not used
Check out the explanation in this short video
- If suffixes such as Ltd, Plc, etc. are not mentioned in the call as part of the official company name, do not include them in the speaker tags.
**South Indian Naming System**
If a name includes an initial (e.g., Y. Delli Babu), treat the initial as the last name and place it at the end. Always follow the standard format: FirstName LastName.
**Audio:** Y. Delli Babu
**Correct Format (Speaker Tag):** Delli Babu Yendluri
üìå Verify the full last name that corresponds to the initial before finalizing.
üëâ Applies to speaker tag formatting only. In the transcript body, always transcribe the name exactly as spoken in the audio.
**Spacing Requirements**
‚úÖ CORRECT: John Doe [CEO and President] (AT&T)
Single space between first and last name
Single space between words in position
Make sure there are no spaces after [ or (
Make sure there are no spaces before ] or )
‚ùå INCORRECT:
John  Doe [ CEO  and  President] ( AT&T ) - Leading/trailing spaces
John Doe [ CEO and President ] ( AT&T ) - Extra spaces inside brackets/parentheses

**Company Name Formatting**
Use exactly as introduced by speaker
Retain abbreviations if spoken (Audio: J&J, use J&J not Johnson & Johnson)
Include official styling when verified

**Operator**
The neutral host for standard earnings calls who manages technical aspects (dial-in instructions, opening/closing remarks, Q&A queue)
**Moderator**
The neutral host at conferences or multi-presenter events who manages the program flow, introduces speakers, and facilitates Q&A.
**FirstName LastName [Position] (Company)**
‚Ä¢ Key executives (CEO, CFO) leading the call 
‚Ä¢ Company representatives (Members of Investor Relations) facilitating Q&A
**FirstName LastName [Position] (Company)**
‚Ä¢ Analysts, shareholders, or private investors asking questions 
‚Ä¢ If substitute speaks for originally introduced participant, use substitute's name
**[Video Narrator]**
The speaker of any pre-recorded voice or commentary played during an earnings call video segment
**[Translator]**
The translator converts non-English speech in the call into English.
**[Analyst]**
‚Ä¢ Name: Unknown, No firstname and last name
‚Ä¢ Role: Analyst (confirmed) 
‚Ä¢ Company: Unknown
**[Analyst] (Company Name)**
‚Ä¢ Name: Unknown 
‚Ä¢ Role: Analyst (confirmed) 
‚Ä¢ Company: Known
‚Ä¢ Name: Only the first name is available; the last name cannot be determined from the transcript or research.
‚Ä¢ Role: Analyst (confirmed) 
‚Ä¢ Company: Known
**[Company Representative]**
‚Ä¢ Name: Unknown 
‚Ä¢ Role: Company Representative (confirmed) 
‚Ä¢ Company: Known
**[Unknown Speaker]**
‚ö†Ô∏èLAST RESORT 
‚Ä¢ No information available at all
‚Ä¢ Cannot determine role or company

*****Substitute Speakers*****
If substitute speaks for originally introduced participant
Use substitute's actual name in tag, not original participant's

**When to use Operator**
Use for single-company earnings calls or regular conference calls.
Think of the operator as a technical facilitator. 

**The operator :**
Gives call instructions (‚ÄúPress *1 to ask a question‚Äù) 
Introduces speakers
Manages the Q&A session *for single-company earnings calls* **NOT** company earnings calls that are part of a larger event. 
üìåThe term ‚Äúconference call‚Äù could just be corporate jargon for a meeting, whether by phone or video.
It does NOT automatically mean a formal, multi-company conference. Think of Zoom as a ‚Äúvideo conferencing‚Äù tool. Same deal. 
*****Example: *****
‚ÄúGood morning, and welcome to the Q3 2025 earnings call for JPMorgan Chase.‚Äù
**When to use Moderator**
Use for multi-company events or large conferences where different companies present throughout the day.
The moderator guides transitions and introduces each company or panel.
*****Example: *****
‚ÄúOur next presentation will be from Pfizer, followed by a Q&A moderated by Jane Smith.‚Äù

**Context is key**. Don‚Äôt rely solely on the word ‚Äúconference‚Äù in the intro. Do your due diligence and verify whether it‚Äôs an independent company call or part of a larger event. 
üìåDual roles can also happen. Moderators can also take on Operator-like tasks, such as giving instructions or managing Q&A.

In summary
Operator = Single company‚Äôs call.
Moderator = Multi-company event or formal conference with multiple presentations.

- **Add numbers only when multiple speakers have identical tags**
*****Examples:***** 
Moderator 1, Moderator 2, [Analyst 1], [Analyst 2], [Unknown Speaker 1], [Unknown Speaker 2]
- **No numbers needed when companies differ:** [Analyst] (AT&T) **and** [Analyst] (Morgan Stanley)

**Two Positions**
‚úÖ CORRECT: [CEO and President]
Use "and" spelled out
‚ùå INCORRECT:
[CEO & President] - Don't use ampersand
[CEO&President] - No spaces with ampersand
[CEOandPresident] - Missing spaces
[CEP, President] - Use of comma instead of ‚Äúand‚Äù

**Three or More Positions**
‚úÖ CORRECT: [Executive Chairman, President, and CEO]
Use Oxford comma (comma before "and")
Use "and" spelled out
‚ùå INCORRECT:
[Executive Chairman, President and CEO] - Missing Oxford comma
[Executive Chairman, President, & CEO] - Using ampersand
[Executive Chairman, President & CEO] - No Oxford comma and using ampersand

If a speaker is introduced with a recognized C-suite role stated in full, use the standard recognized acronym in the tag.
‚ö†Ô∏è Even if the speaker says the full title (‚ÄúChief Executive Officer‚Äù), tag as [CEO].
üìå Important: Only abbreviate in speaker tags, never in the transcript text.
CEO ‚Äì Chief Executive Officer
CFO ‚Äì Chief Financial Officer
COO ‚Äì Chief Operating Officer
CMO ‚Äì Chief Marketing Officer
CTO ‚Äì Chief Technology Officer
CIO ‚Äì Chief Information Officer
CHRO ‚Äì Chief Human Resources Officer
CAIO ‚Äì Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer
VP ‚Äì Vice President
EVP ‚Äì Executive Vice President

If a non-C-suite speaker is introduced with a role stated in full and its acronym could represent multiple positions, do not use the acronym in tags‚Äîretain as full title instead. However, if the non-C-suite role is explicitly dictated in acronym form, use the acronym.
CSO ‚Äì Could mean Chief Strategy Officer, Chief Security Officer, or Chief Sustainability Officer
CRO ‚Äì Could mean Chief Revenue Officer or Chief Risk Officer
CCO ‚Äì Could mean Chief Commercial Officer, Chief Compliance Officer, or Chief Communications Officer
CLO ‚Äì Could mean Chief Legal Officer or Chief Learning Officer
CDO ‚Äì Could mean Chief Data Officer or Chief Digital Officer
CPO ‚Äì Could mean Chief Product Officer or Chief Procurement Officer

‚úÖ Final Note:
 Always prioritize clarity and accuracy in speaker tags.
Use acronyms only when they are explicitly introduced in the audio or are recognized C-suite titles with standard abbreviations.
For non-C-suite roles with acronyms that could mean multiple positions, default to the full title to avoid confusion.
‚ö†Ô∏èRemember: Abbreviations apply only to speaker tags, never to transcript text.

‚úÖ CORRECT:
[Mining Research Analyst] - All major words capitalized
[Senior Analyst] - Proper capitalization
[Equity Research Senior Associate] - Proper capitalization
‚ùå INCORRECT:
[Senior analyst] - Lowercase "analyst"
[mining research analyst] - Improper capitalization

INVESTOR RELATIONS TITLES
IR/Investor Relations Alone
‚ÄúIR‚Äù or ‚ÄúInvestor Relations‚Äù is a department, not a position.
If only ‚ÄúIR‚Äù or ‚ÄúInvestor Relations‚Äù is dictated, do not tag it as the position. Instead, determine the specific role from context or company materials.
	Examples of correct roles:
[Head of Investor Relations]
[VP of Investor Relations]
[Director of Investor Relations]
[Senior Manager of Investor Relations]
[IR Manager]
[IR Associate]
[IR Coordinator]

[Position + Department]
If the speaker is introduced as Position, Investor Relations (e.g., ‚ÄúHead, Investor Relations‚Äù or ‚ÄúExecutive Director, Investor Relations‚Äù), format it with ‚Äúof‚Äù instead of a comma.


‚úÖ CORRECT: [Head of Investor Relations] (AT&T)
‚úÖ CORRECT: [Executive Director of Investor Relations] (Accenture)


‚ùå INCORRECT: [Head, Investor Relations] (AT&T)
	‚ùå INCORRECT: [Executive Director, Investor Relations] (Accenture)

**Finding Complete Names**
- **First/Last name only in audio:** Use Google and context clues to find first/last name
- **Verification sources:**
--LinkedIn profiles
--Company websites (About Us, Leadership pages)
--Recent press releases
--SEC filings for public companies
*****Examples*****
- Audio says "Bob" ‚Üí Research finds ‚Üí Bob Leasure [CEO and President] (Inotiv)
- Audio says "Fred" ‚Üí Research finds Frederick Bell ‚Üí Fred Bell [President and COO] (EMX Royalty)
**Name Consistency**
-  Use one consistent tag per speaker throughout transcript
-  Follow the name as spoken: If a speaker uses a nickname instead of their full name, transcribe the nickname as is (e.g., Rob instead of Robert)"

Identify dominant speaker
Use **[crosstalk]** for unintelligible overlapping speech
Mark unclear sections appropriately

When the audio is AI-generated with a single voice representing all speakers:
- Identify speakers using contextual clues from the conversation content
Listen for:
-- Self-introductions ("This is John from Microsoft...")
-- References to speakers by name ("Thank you, Sarah, for that question...")
-- Role-specific statements (operator instructions, analyst questions, executive responses)
-- Transition phrases indicating speaker changes
- Do not assume speaker continuity based on voice similarity alone
- Verify speaker attribution through:
--Content consistency with speaker's role
--Q&A flow patterns (question from analyst ‚Üí answer from executive)
--Operator cues about who's speaking next
- When uncertain, use contextual markers:
--Company representatives discuss internal metrics
--Analysts ask questions about guidance
--Operators manage call flow
